repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Even if `on_list()` is defined, I don't think this should be called when it is an array with a single element.

comment_regular_data.body:
This PR is not a revert for #19370. Unlike before #19370, it jumps only when it is an array but actually has only one candidate. It does not jump without question.
Shouldn't a Location array with only one element be treated as equivalent to Location?

@mfussenegger I thikn @uga-rosa has a point here.

What #19370 addressed is that it used to **always** jump to the first location, regardless of the number of results.

The fix was to always use the `on_list` handler if it was set, and otherwise jump to the first location if there's only one **and** open the quickfix list.

I have to agree that the logic in this PR makes more sense:

1. If result is a location, or a list of exactly 1 location, then jump to the location
2. else if `on_list` is set, use it
3. else show `qflist`

> I have to agree that the logic in this PR makes more sense

Using `on_list` if it's a list also makes sense.  It's also what's documented

> on_list: (function) handler for list results

`Location[]` a list, independent of the number of items. 

If it makes more or less sense seems a bit subjective to me. The aspect that makes me tend towards the current behaviour is that it gives users the option to still jump in their `on_list` implementation.  If we change the behavior we take away flexibility and users who want to do something other than jumping would have to override the full handler. That's not too difficult either but in the absence of any other substantial arguments it's a tie breaker for me. 


I'm happy to hear any other new arguments.
True. It's also straightforward to add the 1 result logic in their custom `on_list` handler, which is also the default for qflist

The current implementation is certainly more consistent for naming `on_list`. However, some LS implementations return Location if there is one result, while others make location[] even if there is one result. Should users be aware of that subtle difference?

I accept if you say that even if Location is returned, it should be an array and call on_list.

```lua
  if not vim.tbl_islist(result) then
    result = { result }
  end

  local title = "LSP locations"
  local items = util.locations_to_items(result, client.offset_encoding)

  if config.on_list then
    assert(type(config.on_list) == "function", "on_list is not a function")
    config.on_list({ title = title, items = items })
  elseif #items == 1 then
    util.jump_to_location(result[1], client.offset_encoding, config.reuse_win)
  else
    vim.fn.setqflist({}, " ", { title = title, items = items })
    api.nvim_command("botright copen")
  end
```

It is hard to accept that the same number of results can behave differently depending on the implementation of the LS.

Making the behavior consistent/independent of the language server implementations seems a stronger argument.

@rhcher what's your take on this, given that you made the original change?

I'm ok with this change. That's actually what I had in mind at first, but I modified it to what it is now because I had to take into account what the on_list function does.
So we might need to make a little note there in the on_list function that we treat an array of Locations with only one element the same as a single Location.
Do I just update the documentation?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lsp): on_list() expects to be called for two or more candidates
